Florida Big Bend Salt-Brackish Tidal Marsh

references.O91USF01USGP: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. 1991. Endangered and Threatened Wildlife and Plants; Endangered Status for the Florida Salt Marsh Vole. Federal Register 56(9):1457-1459, January 14, 1991.

references.R02DOO01USGP: Doonan, T.J., G.L. Morgan. 2002. Abundance and Distribution of the Florida Salt Marsh Vole (Microtus  pennsylvanicus dukecampbellli) (Project 9314221 1000). habitat_description:
Southeast:
This endangered subspecies is known from only a handful of locations within the transitional high salt marsh zone of central Gulf coastal Florida. Previous studies conducted between 1979 and 2006 document only a few occupied sites north of Cedar Key to Waccassassa Bay (Woods et al. 1982, Bentzien 1989, Smith 1990, Doonan and Morgan 2002, USFWS 2004). Hotaling et al. (2010) repeated trapping in some areas and discovered animals at only a single location on Long Cabbage Key. They appear to be a relict population of M. pennslyvanicus that remained within coastal salt marshes after the Pleistocene when widespread grasslands of Florida converted to forest resulting in habitat shifts for all other populations (Woods et al. 1982). Habitat is restricted to periodically flooded high salt marsh zone of black rush (Juncus roemerianus), and seashore saltgrass (Distichlis spicata) patches while avoiding areas dominated by smooth cordgrass (Spartina alterniflora). They appear to survive high tides and storm flooding by climbing vegetation and swimming (USFWS 1991).
